messageBody:
On 8/29/06, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
>
> >It will probably make your unit tests smaller, but when the bug happens,
> it
> >will take you longer to isolate it because only your acceptance tests
> will
> >fail, and probably in mysterious ways (such as leaking connections).
> >
> >I prefer for my tests to catch bugs as soon as possible (especially in
> this
> >case, where invoking close() will not make them that much slower).
> >
> >
> >
> It's not like that, though. Really, if you make your UTs look like ATs,
> i.e., they run all of these external subsystems, you've just pushed the
> issue of isolating the problem into the UTs. If you write your UTs
> isolated, you have a binary chop. When your UTs pass and your ATs fail,
> it helps you figure out where to look.


We're talking about a JDBC connection here, though. Are you saying you
would write a battery of unit tests that all work on a fake JDBC
connection? This seems like an abuse of mock objects for two reasons:

- JDBC queries can be very fast.
- It's not very hard nor costly to instantiate a JDBC connection, so
the use of mocks is ovekill, IMO.

If you have a class that does nothing but issues SQL queries, unit testing
it means making sure these queries work...

--
